citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
***The male coyote pup housed in the upper level enclosure in the building has a small abrasion or cut beneath his right
eye. The daily observation records which were checked off as completed in the morning do not indicate the presence of
an injury or if any treatment has been provided. There are no other records provided that indicate this injury has been
observed and communicated to the veterinarian. The attending veterinarian was contacted on August 7, 2023 and he was
not aware of the coyote's injury.
Adequate veterinary care includes a mechanism of direct and frequent communication with the veterinarian so that timely
and accurate information on animal health is provided to assure appropriate treatment is provided for the health and
wellbeing of the animal.

***The gravel and rock surface in the primary enclosures for the wolf hybrids "Akila" and "Cujo" does not allow rapid
drainage of water. There are large puddles of water from recent rains in the primary enclosures for the two wolf hybrids.
Standing water can affect the animals ability to stay dry, promote pest infestation, create odors, cause contamination and
create other disease hazards.
A method of rapid elimination of water must be developed and standing puddles of water in animal enclosures must be
drained or mopped up to decrease disease hazards and allow the the animals to stay dry.
Correct by August 16, 2023.

***The first coyote enclosure beside the house which houses two coyotes has a large gravel/rock surface with a wire dig
barrier beneath the rock. Recent rain has washed away some of the rock and substrate in the left corner of the enclosure
leaving a long area with a pocket or gap beneath the wire. The holes in the wire are large enough to allow the coyote to
step into it and become injured.
All gaps between the ground and the dig barrier shall be eliminated to protect the coyotes from injury.
***The top of the den box provided for the singly housed coyote in the second enclosure beside the house is covered with
a sheets of aluminum that has rusted and corroded leaving holes and sharp edges that may cause cuts or other injuries
when the coyotes stand on the den box.
The roof material shall be repaired or replaced and the enclosure shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals
from injury.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Note: The following non-compliances cited on the previous inspection conducted on July 19, 2023 still have time
remaining for correction:
Section 2.40(a) Attending Veterinarian and adequate veterinary Care.
Section 3.13(a) Veterinary Care for Dogs

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
***The male coyote pup housed in the upper level enclosure in the building has a small abrasion or cut beneath his right 
eye. The daily observation records which were checked off as completed in the morning do not indicate the presence of 
an injury or if any treatment has been provided. There are no other records provided that indicate this injury has been 
observed and communicated to the veterinarian. The attending veterinarian was contacted on August 7, 2023 and he was 
not aware of the coyote's injury. 
 
Adequate veterinary care includes a mechanism of direct and frequent communication with the veterinarian so that timely 
and accurate information on animal health is provided to assure appropriate treatment is provided for the health and 
wellbeing of the animal. 
3.1(f) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
***The gravel and rock surface in the primary enclosures for the wolf hybrids "Akila" and "Cujo" does not allow rapid 
drainage of water. There are large puddles of water from recent rains in the primary enclosures for the two wolf hybrids. 
Standing water can affect the animals ability to stay dry, promote pest infestation, create odors, cause contamination and 
create other disease hazards. 
 
A method of rapid elimination of water must be developed and standing puddles of water in animal enclosures must be 
drained or mopped up to decrease disease hazards and allow the the animals to stay dry. 
 
Correct by August 16, 2023. 
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
***The first coyote enclosure beside the house which houses two coyotes has a large gravel/rock surface with a wire dig 
barrier beneath the rock. Recent rain has washed away some of the rock and substrate in the left corner of the enclosure 
leaving a long area with a pocket or gap beneath the wire. The holes in the wire are large enough to allow the coyote to

step into it and become injured. 
 
All gaps between the ground and the dig barrier shall be eliminated to protect the coyotes from injury.  
 
***The top of the den box provided for the singly housed coyote in the second enclosure beside the house is covered with 
a sheets of aluminum that has rusted and corroded leaving holes and sharp edges that may cause cuts or other injuries 
when the coyotes stand on the den box.  
 
The roof material shall be repaired or replaced and the enclosure shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals 
from injury. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
 
Note: The following non-compliances cited on the previous inspection conducted on July 19, 2023 still have time 
remaining for correction: 
 
Section 2.40(a) Attending Veterinarian and adequate veterinary Care. 
Section 3.13(a) Veterinary Care for Dogs
